Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Situation2: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Story:
I sat on the edge of my bed, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my mom’s trembling voice. She rarely opened up, but tonight she poured out her worries about Dad’s health, her loneliness, and how much she needed me. I could hear the hope in her voice, the silent plea for me to come over, to sit with her, to be the daughter she could lean on. My heart ached—I wanted to be there for her, to hold her hand and reassure her that everything would be okay.

But as I hung up, my phone buzzed again. It was Alex, my boyfriend, reminding me about our plans. We’d been looking forward to this evening all week—the only night we’d have together before he left for his business trip. He’d made reservations at my favorite restaurant, and I knew how much this meant to him, to us. I stared at the messages, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My parents needed me. Alex needed me. I felt torn in two, guilt and anxiety swirling inside me as I tried to figure out how to be everything to everyone, knowing I couldn’t.
